SEARCH
Package com.example.chicksevent

Class TEST12_US010601_QRCodeScannerUITest

java.lang.Object
com.example.chicksevent.TEST12_US010601_QRCodeScannerUITest
public class TEST12_US010601_QRCodeScannerUITest extends Object
UI tests for US 01.06.01: As an entrant I want to view event details within the app by scanning the promotional QR code. These instrumented tests verify that:
  • Entrants can navigate to the QR code scanner screen
  • QR code scanner UI elements are displayed correctly
  • Scanner can be started (camera permission handling)
  • After scanning a valid QR code, navigation to event details occurs
  • Event details are displayed correctly (name, description, poster)
Note: For reliable test execution, it's recommended to disable animations on the test device/emulator before running these tests: 
 adb shell settings put global animator_duration_scale 0
 adb shell settings put global window_animation_scale 0
 adb shell settings put global transition_animation_scale 0
To re-enable animations after testing: 
 adb shell settings put global animator_duration_scale 1
 adb shell settings put global window_animation_scale 1
 adb shell settings put global transition_animation_scale 1
Note: Actual QR code scanning requires camera permission and a physical QR code. These tests focus on UI navigation and display. For full end-to-end testing, manual testing with a real QR code is recommended.

    • entrant_canNavigateToQRScannerScreen

      public void entrant_canNavigateToQRScannerScreen()
      Test Case 1: Entrant can navigate to QR code scanner screen. As an entrant, I should be able to navigate to the QR code scanner screen from the main navigation bar.

    • entrant_scannerScreen_displaysInstructions

      public void entrant_scannerScreen_displaysInstructions()
      Test Case 2: QR scanner screen displays instructions. As an entrant, when I open the QR scanner, I should see clear instructions on how to use the scanner.

    • entrant_scannerScreen_displaysStartScanButton

      public void entrant_scannerScreen_displaysStartScanButton()
      Test Case 3: QR scanner screen displays start scan button. As an entrant, I should see a button to start scanning QR codes.

    • entrant_canClickStartScanButton

      public void entrant_canClickStartScanButton()
      Test Case 4: Entrant can click start scan button. VERIFIES FUNCTIONALITY: Start scan button is clickable and triggers scanner.

    • entrant_canNavigateToEventDetails_afterScan

      public void entrant_canNavigateToEventDetails_afterScan()
      Test Case 5: Event details screen displays after navigation. As an entrant, after scanning a valid QR code, I should be navigated to the event details screen.

      Note: This test simulates navigation to event details by directly navigating with a test event ID. In a real scenario, this would happen after scanning a QR code.

    • entrant_eventDetailsScreen_displaysUIElements

      public void entrant_eventDetailsScreen_displaysUIElements()
      Test Case 5b: Event details screen UI elements are present. As an entrant, when I view event details (simulated by direct navigation), I should see the event details screen with all expected UI elements.

      Note: This test directly navigates to EventDetailFragment to verify the UI structure. Actual event data loading requires Firebase setup.

    • entrant_eventDetails_containsExpectedElements

      public void entrant_eventDetails_containsExpectedElements()
      Test Case 6: Event details screen layout contains expected elements. As an entrant, when I view event details after scanning a QR code, I should see the event name, description, poster, and other details.

      Note: This test verifies that the EventDetailFragment layout contains the expected UI elements. Actual data display requires Firebase setup.

    • entrant_scanner_handlesInvalidQRCode

      public void entrant_scanner_handlesInvalidQRCode()
      Test Case 10: QR scanner can handle invalid QR codes. As an entrant, if I scan an invalid QR code (not in the correct format or pointing to a non-existent event), I should see an appropriate error message.

      Note: This test verifies the UI state. Actual error message testing requires scanning invalid QR codes, which is complex in automated tests.

    • entrant_scanner_handlesPermissionDenial

      public void entrant_scanner_handlesPermissionDenial()
      Test Case 11: QR scanner handles camera permission denial gracefully. As an entrant, if I deny camera permission, I should see appropriate messaging and be able to grant permission later.

      Note: Permission handling in UI tests is complex. This test verifies the scanner UI is accessible. Full permission testing requires manual testing or advanced mocking.

    • entrant_canReturnToScanner_afterViewingDetails

      public void entrant_canReturnToScanner_afterViewingDetails()
      Test Case 12: Entrant can return to scanner after viewing event details. As an entrant, after viewing event details from a scanned QR code, I should be able to navigate back to scan another QR code.
